Source   Edit  

POSIX implementation of subprocess management

This module provides the POSIX-specific implementation (Linux, macOS, BSD, etc.) using fork/exec and standard POSIX APIs.

Types

Handle = cint
Source   Edit   
IOHandle = cint
Source   Edit   
ProcessPID = cint
Source   Edit   
Subprocess = ref SubprocessObj
Source   Edit   
SubprocessObj = object
  pid*: ProcessPID
  process_handle*: Handle
  stdin*: IOHandle
  stdout*: IOHandle
  stderr*: IOHandle
  exit_code*: int
  stdoutEof*: bool           ## True when stdout has reached EOF
  stderrEof*: bool           ## True when stderr has reached EOF
Source   Edit   
SubprocessOptions = object
  env*: Table[string, string]
  cwd*: string
  useStdin*: bool
  useStdout*: bool
  useStderr*: bool
  combineStdoutStderr*: bool
Source   Edit  

Procs

proc `=destroy`(subprocess: var SubprocessObj) {....raises: [], tags: [RootEffect],
    forbids: [].}
Destructor to prevent zombie processes Source   Edit   
proc close(subprocess: Subprocess) {....raises: [], tags: [TimeEffect], forbids: [].}

Close subprocess and clean up all resources.

Terminates the process (using SIGKILL) if still running, then closes all pipes (stdin, stdout, stderr).

Example:

let p = startSubprocess(...)
p.close()

Source   Edit   
proc closeStdin(subprocess: Subprocess) {....raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}

Close the stdin pipe to the subprocess.

This signals EOF to the subprocess. Useful after writing all input. Many programs (like cat, wc, etc.) wait for EOF before processing.

Source   Edit   
proc hasDataStderr(subprocess: Subprocess): bool {....raises: [], tags: [],
    forbids: [].}

Check if stderr has data available to read without blocking.

Uses select() with zero timeout for immediate, non-blocking check.

Returns: true if data is available, false otherwise

Source   Edit   
proc hasDataStdout(subprocess: Subprocess): bool {....raises: [], tags: [],
    forbids: [].}

Check if stdout has data available to read without blocking.

Uses select() with zero timeout for immediate, non-blocking check.

Returns: true if data is available, false otherwise

Example:

if p.hasDataStdout():
  let data = p.readStdout()
  echo "Got: ", data

Source   Edit   
proc isRunning(subprocess: Subprocess): bool {....raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}

Check if the subprocess is still running.

This is a non-blocking check using waitpid with WNOHANG. If the process has exited, updates exit_code automatically.

Returns: true if the process is still running, false otherwise

Example:

while p.isRunning():
  let output = p.readStdout(timeoutMs = 100)
  if output.len > 0: echo output

Source   Edit   
proc isStderrEof(subprocess: Subprocess): bool {....raises: [], tags: [],
    forbids: [].}

Check if stderr has reached end-of-file (EOF).

Returns true if a previous read operation encountered EOF, indicating the subprocess has closed its stderr.

Returns: true if stderr has reached EOF, false otherwise

Source   Edit   
proc isStdoutEof(subprocess: Subprocess): bool {....raises: [], tags: [],
    forbids: [].}

Check if stdout has reached end-of-file (EOF).

Returns true if a previous read operation encountered EOF, indicating the subprocess has closed its stdout.

Returns: true if stdout has reached EOF, false otherwise

Example:

while not p.isStdoutEof():
  let data = p.readStdout(timeoutMs = 100)
  if data.len > 0:
    echo data

Source   Edit   
proc readAllStderr(subprocess: Subprocess; timeoutMs: int = -1): string {.
    ...raises: [], tags: [TimeEffect], forbids: [].}

Read all available data from stderr.

Continues reading until no more data is available or timeout expires.

Args: timeoutMs: Total timeout in milliseconds for the entire operation.

-1 means no timeout (reads until EOF or no data available)

Returns: Concatenated string of all data read

Source   Edit   
proc readAllStdout(subprocess: Subprocess; timeoutMs: int = -1): string {.
    ...raises: [], tags: [TimeEffect], forbids: [].}

Read all available data from stdout.

Continues reading until no more data is available or timeout expires.

Args: timeoutMs: Total timeout in milliseconds for the entire operation.

-1 means no timeout (reads until EOF or no data available)

Returns: Concatenated string of all data read

Example:

let allData = p.readAllStdout()
echo "Complete output: ", allData

Source   Edit   
proc readStderr(subprocess: Subprocess; timeoutMs: int = -1): string {.
    ...raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}

Read from stderr with optional timeout.

Reads up to 4096 bytes. For reading all data, use readAllStderr().

Args: timeoutMs: Timeout in milliseconds. -1 means blocking (wait forever)

Returns: String with data read, or empty string if timeout/EOF/error

Source   Edit   
proc readStdout(subprocess: Subprocess; timeoutMs: int = -1): string {.
    ...raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}

Read from stdout with optional timeout.

Reads up to 4096 bytes. For reading all data, use readAllStdout().

Args: timeoutMs: Timeout in milliseconds. -1 means blocking (wait forever)

Returns: String with data read, or empty string if timeout/EOF/error

Example:

# Read with 1 second timeout
let data = p.readStdout(timeoutMs = 1000)
if data.len > 0:
  echo "Read: ", data

Source   Edit   
proc startSubprocess(command: string; args: openArray[string];
                     options: SubprocessOptions): Subprocess {.
    ...raises: [Exception, OSError],
    tags: [ReadDirEffect, ReadEnvEffect, ReadIOEffect], forbids: [].}

Start a new subprocess with the given command and arguments.

Args: command: The program to execute (can be name or full path) args: Command-line arguments (argv1, argv2, ...) options: Configuration options (stdin/stdout/stderr, env, cwd)

Returns: A Subprocess ref object for interacting with the process

Raises: OSError if pipe creation or fork fails

Example:

var opts = SubprocessOptions(useStdout: true)
let p = startSubprocess("ls", ["-la"], opts)
echo p.readAllStdout()
p.close()

Source   Edit   
proc terminate(subprocess: Subprocess; graceful: bool = true) {....raises: [],
    tags: [TimeEffect], forbids: [].}

Terminate the subprocess.

Args: graceful: If true, sends SIGTERM first and waits up to 3 seconds before escalating to SIGKILL. If false, sends SIGKILL immediately.

Example:

# Try graceful shutdown first
p.terminate(graceful = true)

# Force kill immediately
p.terminate(graceful = false)

Source   Edit   
proc wait(subprocess: Subprocess): int {....raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}

Wait for the subprocess to exit and return its exit code.

This is a blocking call that waits until the process terminates.

Returns: The exit code of the process (0 typically means success)

Example:

let exitCode = p.wait()
if exitCode == 0:
  echo "Process succeeded"

Source   Edit   
proc write(subprocess: Subprocess; data: string): int {....raises: [],
    tags: [TimeEffect], forbids: [].}

Write data to subprocess stdin.

Handles partial writes automatically by retrying until all data is written. Handles EINTR, EAGAIN, and EWOULDBLOCK conditions.

Args: data: The string data to write to stdin

Returns: Number of bytes successfully written (should equal data.len on success)

Example:

let written = p.write("hello\n")
if written != 6:
  echo "Partial write or error"

Write data to subprocess stdin. Returns number of bytes written. Handles partial writes automatically.
